text: went out with my first paycheck and
bought a camera I was age 26 carried it
with me every day 40 years it'll be in a
few months every day wherever I've gone
on the street or in bed with someone
I've covered everything through my
camera well being born blind in one eye
was perfect for photography you never
had to close an eye to take a photograph
you never had to change three-dimension
to a flat plane so around 76 at the very
end at 75 my I started seeing through
nets like there are two stockings over
my eyes that are both moving and making
patterns like it was hard to be married
a street sign hard to see people a year
later I started walking with a cane and
my leg was dragging finally yeah
neurologist said I had MS and I said
call me when you got a cure I ain't
coming back not only do I have MS but
now I've also got lung cancer the big
sea god I go back to some of my favorite
photos one is called someone to talk to
and the old man's talking pointing his
finger looking sternly at the dog the
dog is looking at me saying what is he
talking about for 17 years I live in the
Greenwich Village photographed street
life anything on the way to my daily
event
I got my education on the streets that's
why I could take naughty I was
nobody taught me right from wrong
although now that I've hope attendants
take care of me I have to be somewhat
clean cut sherry
go to my right
photograph 2/3 of them now that I can't
hold the camera or press the shutter
release by whoever I'm where they say
help help quickly grab the camera
go a little closer and I get the shots 1
out of 10 are exactly as I wished they
would be others I have to crop a bit and
you still say you're not a photographer
we're on the way did the drugstore and I
said more about take a picture of that
and she said what that piece of junk
I said it's not junk you'll see when you
take the picture make sure you get all
six points in and she did it she's still
in understand but now every time we see
on television the Israeli flag
I say look there's your photo
I looked at them buildings being built
and I went close closer and looked up
Wow
those are the World Trade Center
buildings so what did I do
I snuck in the guard said what are you
doing here I said I'm here enough
photographed the building I touched his
hand gently could you take me up there
yeah hot chick he said sure and one day
I called the city asked them if they
could build a ramp on a certain corner
they didn't have funding for it so I
bought the cement and built my first
ramp sometimes people would see me
sitting beside my wheelchair troweling
this a man they say miss are you okay
can I help you
I'd say yeah can you mix the cement
please it's amazing to live two blocks
from all this excite
since I started becoming disabled at age
30 I got used to the idea that ain't
gonna be what I used to be I guess it's
hard being not a hot chick anymore and
getting freebies and talking your way
into places although I can push
disability I use whatever I've got most
important is to continue in a different
style I'm glad I took all the pictures
because now I have time to put them all
together and you got to think of the
future and what you can do with your
life to keep your interest going
